But exceedingly rare is finding exquisite presentation combined with family style portions (and low$ !) on top of fresh (I mean hand-picked  kind of fresh) vegetables that are allowed to star as the feature of the dish, instead of the normal wilted-and-greased-to-someone's version-of-satisfaction torture that vegetables often undergo in Asian cuisine. That's why I keep going back to Thai Idea. My parents are quite the LA food critics, and my dad can't stop visiting me specifically for this place...I told him to pretend he's actually coming to see me, but he needs to work on his poker face. I digress. Get the pumpkin curry. And the lychee iced tea. It's ahhhmazing. And no reservations required...unless I just let the secret out. Oops
author: Lauren D.

description:
I first happened upon Thai Idea after going to a show in the Civic Center area with my mom.  We were seeking something both of us would enjoy, and I managed to persuade my mom to go to a vegetarian place since she likes Thai food so much.  Luckily, she wasn't disappointed.

We ordered spring rolls as an appetizer, and they accidentally gave us someone else's samosas instead.  I was thinking they were a strange shape for spring rolls but didn't question it.  When they realized their mistake, they gave us the spring rolls too and didn't charge us for the extra appetizer.  Needless to say, we had lots of leftovers as a result, but we didn't mind.  Everything tasted fantastic, and they have a creative way of displaying their food on oddly shaped dishes.  It was my mom's first time trying fake meat, and she liked it a lot.  I have since come back with my boyfriend and enjoyed it just as much the second time around.
author: Laura W.

description:
This was a delicious place to eat. The decor was nice and the service was good, too. 

We enjoyed the Tom Kha soup, veggie red curry, pumpkin curry and Wing Bomb. Seriously delicious!!! The veggies were cooked perfectly and the food seasoned just right.

I  wasn't crazy about the pad basil, it was okay, but tasted more like oversalted Chinese food.I didn't care for the fake meat in the Tom Kha soup either. 

The mango and sticky rice dessert was beautifully presented and equally as good tasting. We had the Jasmine tea, which was just right.

The *must have* item while there: Wing Bomb appetizer!

Would definitely visit this place again if in SF.
author: Sonoma D.

description: AMAZING! Thank you for serving authentic, vegan food. Go try it, you won't be disappointed!
author: C R.

description:
My fiance and I love Thai Idea. We go almost every week - and try our best to try different dishes. We have taken family and friends there, and all of them have loved it. My friends (who are not vegetarian) really enjoyed their food, and our family (who are vegetarian) also really enjoyed their meals.

Our favorite dishes include:

1. Panang Curry
2. Pad Eggplant 
3. Firecracker Balls
4. Pad Thai
5. Cashew Nut 
6. Pineapple Fried Rice

One of our must go-to restaurants!
author: Vrinda S.

description:
We really wanted to like Thai Idea more, but have been fortunate to have some incredible Thai in other cities (disclaimer:  we are not vegans).

Based on other Yelp reviews, we started with the Wing Bombs.  Different for us, but very tasty - a but more chewy than expected though.

On to the standards for us - Pseudo-shrimp Pad Thai and Pineapple Rice.  Both were very good, but not nearly as good as some of our favorites.  Despite this, we were surprised how good they were, and yet were vegan.

The service was exceptionally friendly and attentive.
author: Doug C.

description:
Ambiance: 4 out of 5
Thai Idea's decor is modern, stylish, and new. The only reason why I didn't give it 5 stars is because the seating could be slightly more comfortable.

Pumpkin Curry: 5 out of 5
Wow. This was hands-down the best curry dish I've ever had and possibly one of the best meals I've ever had. I could tell from the first bite that this was a dish I would remember and crave and possibly try to recreate later at home. The pumpkin curry sauce was deliciously flavorful without being too heavy or viscous. It coated the vegetarian beef filets, starchy pumpkin cubes, and bell peppers. The dish was topped with crispy yam slivers, which were a brilliant addition and textural contrast. Accolades all around for this culinary delight! As an aside, as I was enjoying, I looked up at some of my fellow diners and one man to the right of me had pretty much cleaned his bowl of pumpkin curry and another guy in the front of the restaurant had just received his order. Apparently, this is a popular dish. (If you're interested in checking out the dish, I uploaded a picture above.)

Larb Salad: 3.5 out of 5
This salad consisted of soy ground protein chicken, coarsely chopped raw red onions, mint leaves, rice powder, a generous dusting of chili powder, and light lime dressing. The mint was a bit overpowering and it may have been if there were other greens to balance out the strong flavor. I'm also not sure why they used mint, as opposed to cilantro. The soy chicken was flavorful. The portion size was huge; two people could easily split this as an appetizer. (If you're interested in checking out the dish, I uploaded a picture above.)

Service: 4 out of 5
Service was attentive, water refills were regular, and the speed of the meal was at a comfortable pace.

Overall: 4.5 out of 5
I'm currently dreaming about the pumpkin curry. Go here. Now. And get the pumpkin curry.
author: Paige B.

description:
The pad see you and pineapple fried rice are both delicious.  The neighborhood is a bit scary - if you're walking over from downtown, don't take Ellis.  Macallister may be better.  

The seats are hard wood, so not particularly conducive to lounging after a big starchy and vegetably meal.  

Their bathroom door tells you not to leave your bags alone whilst you're headed towards the bathroom.  My partner cleverly remarked that if you see the sign when you're already at the bathroom then it's a bit too late.
author: Di Yin L.

description:
Heading to the City for a concert with a (carnivore) friend, and we decided to try Thai Idea Vegetarian for the first time.  The food sounded good, was reasonably priced, and was fairly close to the venue.   The place is intimate (read smallish) and off the beaten path a bit.  The decor was attractive and the restaurant had a nice ambiance.  The service people were friendly and attentive.  The food came quickly with a good temperature...hot but not scalding.  

What can I say...the food was AWESOME!  Not just because it was a vegetarian Thai restaurant, but because the food was AWESOME!   I have eaten at some vegetarian restaurants that were awful, and I eat at non-vegetarian Thai restaurants fairly often.  The food here was far and above any Thai restaurant I have been to in a long time...and to top it off I could eat anything on the menu.  So fun!  

My friend, a meat eater, thought the food was great, too.  My friend had the crispy egg roll appetizer, the "beef' Volcano, and the "beef" green curry.  I had the Wing Bomb appetizer, the "chicken" Pad Thai, and the yellow "beef" curry. I get Pad Thai pretty much every time I eat Thai food, sometimes it's good, sometimes its not so good.  This Pad Thai was fabulous...great flavor and texture.  The yellow curry was made with "beef," potatoes, and onions steeped in a delicious coconut milk yellow curry sauce, with just the right amount of spice (OMG...I am still craving that amazingly delectible curry...yum!!!).   My friend and I shared some Jasmine rice, and we both had iced lychee drinks (very refreshing).  I normally would have ordered a Thai iced tea, but after I tasted my friend's lychee drink, I had to have one, too.  

The food was plentiful and was served in unusually shaped bowls, which added to the character of the restaurant.  We were so full we could not finish the food nor did we order dessert.  We got 2 appetizers, 4 entrees, rice, and 3 drinks for just over $70...very reasonable.  I can find absolutely no fault with this place, so count 'em...5 stars!  And although it is pretty obvious, yes, I would definitely dine there again, and so should you!!!
author: Veg Gal R.

description:
Let me preface this review by saying I'm not a huge fan of Thai food, I usually only go when I'm with friends who ask for Thai.  Given that I'm the only vegan in my circle of friends, they are already putting up with enough dietary pickiness from me, so I don't complain when I dine out with buddies as long as there is some sort of vegan option.

In this case my sweet friend found this lovely vegetarian and almost completely vegan spot for my to try.  How awesome is that!  I suppose I was immediately inclined to like it, and I did.

First and best of all, they serve no booze!  Why is this great?  Because you can buy booze next door and bring it in.  This saves you HUGE dollars on the bill.

Overall the dishes were good.   It gets 4 stars instead of 3 because of all the vegan options and because of the booze factor.  Oh and the prices are good too.  This will be a very good, very cheap dinner in a place with a very nice little atmosphere.  It's hip and cozy, and it doesn't have that "fast food to go" feel that some asian restaurant do.

On to the food...

Golden Cauliflower:  I didnt' realize this would be deep fried, I don't usually order deep fried.  But it was soooooo good everyone loved it. I suppose deep fried is always good.  

Satay Chicken:  I'm not a big fan of immitation meat, but this was good. My husband and our friend really liked it.  (gosh, I'm started to realize WHAT A PICKY EATER i am, lol - I swear I usually find things to like).

Som Tum:  This was a nice big portion, but overall they made it way too sweet for me.  It's a green papaya salad and I know it's a common/famous dish in thai restaurants, maybe it's always this sweet? I just found it waaaay too sweet.

Spicy Lemongrass Beef:  Good!  A nice curry.  Lots of nice veggies.  Not too sweet.  

Brown rice:  Sooo nutty and tasty.  Why can't I make brown rice this delicious at home????
author: Evelyn N.

description:
I have never eaten "fake" chicken that tasted so much like real chicken!! The presentation of the food was superb. The food tasted excellent. The quantities were enough to fill us up. The complementary soup was very yummy as well. 

We loved the unique interior, the fast service and friendly waiters. Will definitely be back when I visit San Francisco. I wish they had a branch in San Jose.
author: nora n.

description:
Good Veggie food with very nice decoration and good staff..
We tried Pad Thai, Crab cake, Wing bombs and Mango with Sticky rice.
One of the best Mango with Sticky rice..
Pad thai was also very good. Crab cakes were better than wing bombs but both of them were not as good as lot people mentioned in their reviews.. I felt that they were overrated. Presentation was very beautiful.. Will definitely go to try different stuff. I hope they are more places like this..
author: Ketan J.

description:
I was in SF for a conference last month and ended up eating here 3 times in 5 days.

Their pumpkin curry is nothing short of spectacular. Eating in adds their impeccable presentation to already delicious food. I also tried the faux shrimp and firecracker balls. Both really good but not quite up to the level of the pumpkin curry, oh so good...
author: Justin O.

description:
I went here for my birthday dinner and couldn't have asked for more in a venue. When we called in to make the reservation we asked if it would be cool if we brought our own booze (as they don't have a bar) and they were all about it. No cork fee, no restrictions, no questions asked. Sold! 

When our party of 9 arrived they swiftly made way for us and catered to our every need politely and quickly. Being a first time, I  asked what appetizers the server recommended and she was spot on with some yummy chicken skewers, fried cauliflower and salad rolls. All together we ordered 4 starters and probably 5 or so entrees and everyone (Vegan, veggie and carnivore alike) left with full bellies AND wallets. Everything from start to finish was under $100. And did I mention that everything was delicious?! Because it really was. The presentation was great, too. 

Many thanks to the good people of Thai Idea Vegetarian for their high culinary standards and tolerance for libation-bearing  groups!
author: Ashley S.

description:
Dear Neil W.

There's nothing you could compare this place with King of Thai Noodle House. Their price is cheaper, that is correct, but nothing can compare with the quality, cleanness, and deliciousness which I yield to pay for. Every time when I eat out here, I always order Fresh Rolls whose taste is always the same. If you didn't like it, it might not because of food itself. 

If you would like to have such a tasty food, Thai Idea Vegetarian might not be the best place for you. Since it's vegetarian, I would love to have clear and clean food rather than tasty, but tearing my health apart. King of Thai Noodle use a bunch of MSG. Thai Idea Vegetarian has never used MSG in any dish. It's not puzzling me if you like King of Thai Noodle way better. 

and there's nothing wrong with your yelp friends. Everyone can have different attitude and opinion. If you don't like it, just give only your opinion and expect other opinion. That's how Yelp works!

Anyway, I always get the same good service and same taste of food at Thai Idea Vegetarian :)
author: Abbey L.

description:
Probably the best place in the city to go to for vegetarian thai food.
They have a huge selection, large portions, a really nice dining area and the servers are pretty nice!
Have add their musamman curry 2wice and it was pretty good on both occasions.. The thai samosas are pretty awesome as well!
author: Aditya M.

description:
The Tom Yam was decent.

The Vindaloo was good, but I don't think that is really Thai (or Indian, for that matter).

I guess I'm just not into the whole "fake meat" thing.

Also, the decor on the right side of the restaurant is fine. But on the left, not so much.
author: Wes F.

description:
Don't shoot me -- but I'm usually a carnivore :X.  As I was feeling a bit "holiday fat," I came to here as my idea of a healthier lunch.  Short of it is, I don't think my meal was contained any fewer calories than non-vegan Thai -- BUT, it was extremely tasty and the overall experience was wonderful.

If you ignore the view of the tendorloin mess outside the window, the restaurant looks quite upscale and has a superb ambience.  Staff is super attentive and friendly too.  

For food we ordered:
--Tofu Pumpkin Curry ($8.95) -- Amazing presentation and even better taste.  A very light curry that I suspected has less cream than other curries.  Served with a tower of brown rice. 
--Veggie Chicken Pad See Ew ($7.95) -- My first time trying "veggie chicken" -- while it doesnt taste like chicken (and I wonder if there'd be any difference if i ordered "veggie duck"), the texture of the faux meat was great -- as was the flavor.  The noodles were cooked to the dark brown that I like with a lot of "wok hei" (flame flavor).  There was about two tablespoons too much oil in the dish -- so I'd ask to go easy on the oil next time.  Again, great presentation and big portions.

Probably would trek to this area late at night -- but I'll definitely return for another lunch with any of my vegetarian buddies!
author: Kendra W.

description:
I *really* wanted to write a 5-star review of Thai Idea.  After all, I'm a veg*n, Thai Idea is located just a few blocks from my home, and they have a very impressive menu.  Added to that, the servers were charming and helpful, and the space is appealing.  However, a number of problems came up that prevent me from giving them a higher rating.

First, I telephoned in a takeaway order for an appetizer and two entrees, based upon their website's current menu.  The total price they quoted to me on the phone was a few dollars more than what their on-line menu came to, which confused me.  Also, I asked the young woman on the phone to make my entree _mild_.  She repeated my order back thus, so I presume that she understood it.  Not only do I find spicy food unpleasant to eat, it's really hard on my digestive system, so I have to make it a point to specify "mild".  And "mild" means "mild", not "contains 10% less cayenne than 'regular'".

We walked over to pick up the order, and the young lady at the counter first got confused and handed us someone else's order but, suspecting that it was incorrect, we asked her what dishes it contained.  Sure enough, our order was in a different bag.  Not a serious problem -- unless, of course, we hadn't caught the mistake until we had gotten home.  

Also, we discovered why it was $3 more than the on-line menu stated: the prices on the paper menus, from which they reckon things, were $1 more for each of the dishes.  Call me old-fashioned, but I believe that the prices listed on your website are what a restaurant should charge their customers who are calling in orders from it (and the laws of State of California agree).  And $10 for a veggie entree is a bit steep, especially compared to neighborhood competitors like Golden Era.

When we *did* get home, we broke into the food.  We started with crab cakes, which were quite good, and unlike anything else I've had in veggie form.  I'd definitely get them again.  I had ordered Pad See-Ew with shrimp.  It was tasty, but on a hotness scale of zero to ten (with zero being absolutely bland and ten being the hottest thing I've ever eaten), it was about a 4; too spicy for me to really enjoy.  I even found red pepper flakes in the sauce.  'Twas a shame, since the other flavors were quite nice, but they were largely drowned out by heat.

I would like to raise my rating of Thai Idea, and to try it again (and will likely do so).  But they need to make a few changes before I'm willing to give them more stars.  They need to be careful to charge their customers the prices that are listed, or at the very least, explain why they're charging more than the listed prices.  They need to take patrons seriously when they ask for dishes to be prepared "mild".  And they need to be very careful to double-check that they're giving patrons the correct order.  Nothing ruins a dining experience like being given someone else's order, and not discovering it until you get home.  

If Thai Idea can do these things, I'll be happy to raise their rating commensurately.  I want to enjoy their food and I want them to succeed.  Whether or not that happens is entirely up to them.
author: Curran H.

description:
Came here for the spicy catfish reading they positive reviews and since it is included as chef's special. The dish looked good and flavored very well. Still wondering why i am giving 1 star? The veggie catfish pieces were very thin seemed over-deep fried as each piece was hard and cruchy with no taste as no texture. As a teaser, there were just one of two pieces that were kind of juicy on the inside and crunchy on the outside, giving me an idea of how good this dish could have been. Not sure whether I was unlucky in getting an over-fried dish or the dish is made that way. If it is made that way, it is certainly not for me. Plus, I walked 1.5 miles from my work just to try this, and you can understand how disappointed I must have been. Don't think I will come here again as I have tried some of their other dishes in the past and did not feel their mock meat was as good as many people are raving in yelp or available elsewhere. 

What surprises me is I see so many reviews saying the food is cheap here. I
 don't understand what is cheap. Personally I feel their dishes are very pricey and not worth the money or walk for me. The lunch specials all are $10 (+ tax & tip) or more, plus the curry entrees does not come with rice. So you look at spending at least $11.50 for a lunch. The spicy catfish was like $12.50 plus bought a rice, so total bill was a little less than $16. $16 for a meal for one person is too pricey for me, which I could have digested had it been good. If the dish was alteast in the $10 range and came with rice I could give it 2 stars. Sometimes I feel the restaurant people are just putting fake 5 star reviews, as no sane person would say it is cheap, irrespective of whether they like the food or not.
author: Anthony S.

description:
Huge fan! The presentation is beautiful - each dish is brought out looking exquisite & not what you're expecting from a restaurant in the T-loin. It always has people in there for dinner - the only time I've been around that area.

My friend & I shared the cauliflower balls - fried florets of cauliflower in a really light batter laid on a long plate with some sweet sauce and shaved carrots. Yum.

I got the Pumpkin Curry w/ "chicken" (all fake meat) & brown rice. The rice was perfect. The curry was amazing - not spicy not the menu states (1 star for spicy compared to other dishes w/ 3 stars!). The cubes of pumpkin were fork-tender & made me swoon. The faux-chicken isn't something I'd do again though. Brown, flat pieces of "chicken" that tasted a bit slimy & chewy (when tasted alone but when eaten in combo w/ the dish I didn't notice as much). Next time, I'll stick w/ tofu. 

My friend got a noodle dish w/ tofu. (the middle choice on the noodle options on the menu). Full of veggies & wide noodles, it was good too.

Too full for dessert, but I plan on going back often to make my tongue tingle the way it did on my 1st experience. If I could talk my office into catering from this place I would.

Other reviews are right: 1 girl who seats, takes orders, refills glasses, & takes care of check. Another woman - 1 of (I think 2 total) cooks - brought us the food. Agreed that the TV should be taken out & replaced with a painting. Would be cool to see some Thai beer or wine on the menu as well; but BYOB is also an option (didn't see a corkage fee either)

As a vegetarian convert, I'm highly appreciative of this place. Not only is it vegetarian/vegan, it doesn't use fish/oyster sauce in any cooking, the presentation is gorgeous & the prices are more than reasonable. I smell a success! (I'm so cheesy....)
author: Marissa H.

description:
Woohoo! I came here for dinner on my last birthday and had the BEST time, due not only to my amazing friends but to Thai Idea's delicious food, great service, and acceptance of outside adult beverages! We sipped on champagne and beer from the neighboring liquor store and chowed awesome food: appies like the Wing Bomb, beloved Thai curries and the like. Almost everything on the menu is vegan so this is a must-try for you veggie types.

They were very gracious toward our big, rowdy group and we all had a great time and loved the food. I hesitate to give five stars based on just one visit, but my birthday dinner was so great I just have to! I'll be back for sure!
author: Jami W.

description:
Open for just a month, the restaurant has a lovely ambiance. The interior is dark and pillows line the bench seats against the wall. Candles light each table and soft music competes with the car alarms outside. There is a lengthy menu featuring traditional Thai fare with appetizers, soups, curries, noodle dishes, and chef's specials. Their curries, noodles, and other dishes can be ordered with chicken, beef, tofu, vegetables, or shrimp-all vegetarian of course.

The menu was overwhelming, so we asked our server for suggestions. She was very knowledgeable about the menu and quick to make recommendations. In the end, we got the crab cake appetizer, green curry with vegetarian chicken, and the Bangkok Duck.

Every dish was awesome. The Bangkok Duck was beautifully presented and really tasty. 

It was quiet when we were there, the service was great--attentive yet not too attentive. 

They don't have beer and wine, but you can bring your own and they don't charge a corkage fee. A new favorite veg restaurant in SF.
author: Kristie M.

description:
I absolutely LOVE this place! If you either like Thai food or are vegetarian, you'd love this place. If you're both you'd love this place. If you just eat period, you'd love this place.

Basically, all the food here tastes like great regular, non-vegetarian Thai food, except that it's all vegetarian. My favorite dishes are the chicken yellow curry and pineapple fried rice, and both were just as moist and packed full of flavor as their meat counterparts. There's a large selection of other most everything else you'd expect to find on a Thai menu though, and the portions are very generous.

Popular things I'd stay away from: the firecracker ball and wing bombs. They're not really bad per se, but weird fusion dishes that seem really out of place and not that good in comparison with the otherwise excellent authentic Thai dishes on the menu.

It's in the middle of the Tenderloin, so not the nicest area, but this is definitely one of my favorite spots in the city for affordable, delicious Thai and vegetarian food.
author: Phong Q.

description:
This is one of my favorite places in the city.The attention to presentation is matched only by the utterly delicious taste of every dish I have tried so far. My favorite is the Beef Vindaloo Curry (veggie "meat" of course) with white rice.

Bring your own alcohol is just fine with me. They pop the cork for you or open and pour your beer or whatever you have, they accomodate. *** EDIT, they no longer have the BYOB option, I guess they got a liquor license.

The only thing that has ever been an issue is the noise level. It gets pretty loud when the place is full. I guess people are just having a good time but damn, it's like a high school lunchroom sometimes! This does not deter me from patronizing this fine establishment in any way.
author: Tyson H.

description:
WOW! This was the best Thai Food I have ever had; and I live in Thai Town. 
The staff was very helpful and accommodating! Loved the selection, beautiful decor! The food was extremely flavorful, the presentation was artistic and elegant!
author: Harutik V.

description:
Went here for a group dinner and could not have been more impressed with the service and food.  Veggie duck confit? Yes please!

There were so many of us that we didn't order individually, instead they just kept bringing out food to us. The appetizers, entrees, and desserts were delicious and we had tons of left overs. 

The hospitality was amazing, the service was speedy, and we felt taken care of. I recommend this for a quick dinner/lunch or large group dinner.
author: Sam Marie G.

description:
We decided to walk here from Union Square after some Black Friday mayhem. I'm not from the SF area so walking through the Tenderloin district at 9 PM was a little nerve wrecking for me. You pass by some shady hotels and some shady people until you hit this quaint little Thai restaurant. The food was good; we had the pineapple fried rice and some noodle dish with a side of peanut sauce. The shrimp was a little weird, I think they make it out of gluten. Most fake meat uses gluten so be warned celiac disease sufferers! It was reasonably priced and was very filling. It wasn't heavy or greasy which Asian food can be. I had the lychee iced tea while my friend had the thai tea which were both very delicious. 

Funny note: A gentleman at another table had asked how spicy is spicy, and the waitress didn't quite understand. So, he just ordered medium, and it was obviously way too spicy as he was downing lots of water and turned bright red.
author: Sophia M.

description:
This place is in the Tenderloin, so sketchiness abounds, but what definitely is NOT sketchy is the food at Thai Idea. Who knew!? I am not vegetarian, but I didn't miss the meat because the flavors were overwhelmingly good! We started with the firecracker balls--WIN! We all liked our entrees: red curry with veggie chicken, pad kee mao with fried tofu, and the veggie duck.  We ended our meal with the thai crepe.  Can I just say that this dessert was about as perfect as it gets--fluffy crepe with chocolate drizzle and organic coconut ice cream. I DIE!  They really care about the presentation of their food and service here, too. A bright fuchsia orchid adorned every plate!

I'm a fan!
author: Emille L.

description:
A nice alternative to Golden Era. I'm happy more vegan restaurants are popping up, especially gems like this one. 
I got my food to go but the ambiance seemed relaxing and inviting inside. Staff was very friendly and I like that! The food was so good. I got the yom woon sen salad and the tom gha pra soup. Basic stuff but the cook there knows what time it is. Good job Thai Idea. It's really nice not having to keep repeating "no fish, no oyster sauce please" cuz it's all vegan/vegetarian. I'll be back for sure. 
Good Luck. Much love.
author: Daniel A.

description: Absolutely awesome food! GREAT SERVICE! Pure Mansavilat!!!! Definitely coming back again soon!
author: T V.

description:
I was pre-disposed to like this place, as one of my favorite restaurants in my last city was very similar (My Thai in Boston).  In Boston, we'd perfected our order: Tom Yum, Papaya Salad, and Tamarind Duck.  To our delight, we recreated two of the dishes - the Papaya Salad and the Tamarind Duck (called the Bangkok Duck here).  We also tried the Pad Basil.  Everything was delicious, generous in portion, and plated beautifully.

We'll definitely be back.
author: Allison B.

description: The location is not the safest but get a ride here or walk here with friends, because the food is worth it! This is a nicely decorated restaurant and the service was very quick. The waitresses are friendly. It's great to have a vegetarian place with so many high quality options. Try the pad thai!
author: Dhwani T.

description:
Where to start...
Authentic.... What do I mean by that...  

If you've been to Thai restaurant, vegan/vege or not, then you know the disappointment of overly sweet, water down, less savory echos of quickly made Thai food. 

Thai Idea delivers deep flavors that are not held back, presentation was perfect, and I found myself experiencing an unexpected 5 star moment of bliss. One word of advice, they do not tone down the spice for, I am guessing, the typical American palate as they should not, so when requesting hotness of your food drop it down one notch....ie. if you like it medium go with mild, if you like it mild perhaps no heat for you. If you want a real experience let them spice it how it should be, you will not be disappointed.

6 stars for the cuisine
5 stars for the comfy yet artistic environment
5 stars for presentation
5 stars for the price considering all of the above ($7-10 for entree) 
5 stars for the friendly wait staff and the owner checking how the meal went

I only wish this place was in Berkeley and I didn't have to go into the city for something this good.

Even the bathroom was nice and upscale.
author: Wish W.

description: Love this place!  Their pad see ew has a smokiness to it that is truly addictive.  I am not a huge fan of some of the "meat" dishes, but anything that is actually vegetarian is flavorful and delicious.  And their curries are also yum!
author: Asha E.

description:
Z.O.M.G.

I read rave reviews and had high expectations, most if not all of which were met.

I went on a Wednesday after work. It was quiet, intimate, beautiful, and with attentive service.

Food came out tiered so that we could enjoy one dish at a time. 

Had the papaya salad (amazing!) wingbombs (amazing-texture AND flavor) and Bangkok duck (meh, was so-so.)

Not super pricey, but lovely, and I believe that all dishes can be made vegan. Their fake-meats were spot-on in terms of texture and flavor and the presentation of all of the dishes was beautiful.
author: Kim L.

description: It's good for being vegan but I wouldn't come back. Ordered the drunken noodles, cashew but tofu...it was all ok. The chicken in the cashew nut tofu was a bit much. Excellent service and flexibility esp with our two kids under the age of 3. Probably not coming back.
author: Mansi P.

description:
Review of Service:

I went in to grab a mango & sticky rice dessert to go before the fireworks yesterday. When it came out, I saw the mango was the green type of mango, and that the sticky rice had sesame as garnish.
It's a pet peeve of mine when there are ingredients in my food that weren't mentioned in the menu (if I knew there'd be sesame, I would have said something beforehand), but it happens so much that I should probably just get over it :p lol *sigh*
When I asked the hostess about the mango, she said, "yes, right now the sweet mangoes aren't in season maybe."(having green mangoes is something a server should mention, because it's NOT the norm for this dessert, but some patrons may still opt for it) I explained that I wish this issue was expressed when I ordered because I'm not OK with tart/sour foods. (I could have saved us both the time :P)
The reason I'm giving my visit 4 stars is because mistakes are made, but the service was VERY friendly and customer oriented. She understood the problem and promptly returned my money. The minus one star is for not communicating the food issue when I placed my order, and because their website states they have not only coconut vegan ice cream, but regular vanilla as well. The website needs to be updated to reflect their no longer having the vanilla, and other items that have also changed.
author: Awesomeness S.

description: Fantastic place. Not only is the food delicious but the presentation is perfect too. Staff is super friendly. My new favorite vegetarian place.
author: Robert J.

description:
There are better Thai restaurants in the City.  But Thai Idea is the only vegetarian Thai restaurant in the City.  They've got that going for them.  

The pros:  Wonderful service, beautiful presentation, nice atmosphere.

But where it counts, the food fails to deliver.  The peanut sauce was bland, as was the satay chicken.  I ordered the crispy chicken expecting it to be different from the BBQ chicken, but it was just the BBQ chicken with a coating of fried batter.  The fried rice that it topped was very average.  My friend's Pad Kee Mao was nothing out of the ordinary.  (They are very good about making a dish genuinely spicy if requested, however.)  It was not busy, but the fresh spring rolls were mysteriously unavailable for order during lunch.

They undoubtedly fill a niche that's been dying to be filled since Mekong, which served wonderful Veggie Thai food, closed several years ago.  As a vegetarian, it's always a pleasure to order Thai and not have to worry about fish or oyster sauce inundating your entrees and dips.  But I'd rather they spend the energy they use to window dress their plates to flavoring up their food instead.

I'd give them another chance; I'd really like them to succeed, but they need a bit of tough love.  Because as it stands, Ken's Kitchen Chinese restaurant at the end of the block has great fake meat (though you'd never guess from the outside).  For Thai, Modern Thai further up Polk has never failed to satisfy.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
I stumbled upon this place on my way home and ever in search of new veggie joints had to check it out !

I ordered pumpkin (kabocha) curry, one of my thai favorites and was not disappointed -- my dish was a rich orange color, spicy,  fragrant and creamy. My dinner companion had a stir-fry dish with a good mix of vegetables and faux meat, nice seasoning and very spicy!

Everything was beautifully presented and service was really friendly. I'm really impressed for a restaurant just getting started and predict this place will quickly become a SF vegan/vegetarian staple.

I will return again, and must try a few more dishes!
author: Dana S.

description:
The best vegetarian meal I have had in recent memory.  Take out the oyster sauce, take out the fish sauce, enter soy sauce and get great food.

The place is a gem in the Tenderloin - cute, clean, classy, and delicious.  We ate Pad Eggplant (SO GOOD) and the Pad See Ew.  Both were outstanding and Thai Idea is going to become a favorite!
author: Chad S.

description:
I finally got a chance to try this place out. I've read about it in articles and blogs, plus Yelpers praise this place! I went with my boyfriend and even though he is not vegetarian, he does not mind eating fake meat and is always willing to try it (but this guy is a meat lover and probably would not turn vegetarian).

This place is really cute. It has a modern Thai ambiance. I like the pillows laid out on some sitting areas, plus I like the color decor of browns and greens. I really loved the tree art they had near the register... very cute! I opened the menu and I was just overwhelmed by all the dishes and options! I wanted to order everything. After debating over what we wanted, here is what we ended up ordering:

APPETIZER - CRAB CAKES (Vegan)
We opted for the vegan, because my boyfriend  freaked when he heard the word "egg" (the one piece of food he hates). These were delicious! I never really had a crab cake in my life, since I am allergic to shellfish so I really can't compare them to regular crab cakes. These were crunchy, had a slight "crab/fish" taste, and had a very flavorful sauce that went on top of the cakes. It also came with a few pieces of potato wedges on the plate, which was a little treat. He also enjoyed them and we devoured these really fast!

PINEAPPLE BROWN FRIED RICE
I do not eat white rice, so when I asked to substitute the fried rice with brown... I was glad that she was willing to do so! I did not want to just order plain brown rice, because the description of the pineapple fried rice sounded too good to pass up.  The menu said: pineapple, chicken, shrimp, and some other veggies... but when it came out it the dish had other ingredients in it. One, instead of chicken it was beef... Then as I mentioned, my boyfriend hates egg, so we usually order fried rice without egg. We assumed that since the menu didn't list egg we didn't have to worry, but it had it when we got it. He was really disappointed but sucked it up and still ate it. I think this partly ruined his dinner, and I felt bad but he insisted that we not order a plain bowl of rice since there was so much food. To me, it was good but something tasted a little off to me. I can't really describe the taste but I did not like it and the taste kept creeping into my nose. I was drowning it with the curry to not taste it.

PUMPKIN CURRY WITH BEEF
This was yummy! My boyfriend always orders pumpkin curry, so of course he had to get it here. I really enjoyed the crispy strips of sweet potato on top, plus this curry was full of flavors! I liked the texture of the squash/pumpkin, which was soft and mushy. The fake beef was good, but was a little too chewy.

AVOCADO SHRIMP PANANG CURRY
This is the dish I ordered and I thought the avocado complimented the curry really well! I was a little hesitant to order at first because I would never think about having avocado in my curry, but I loved it a lot. The shrimp didn't really taste like what I remember shrimp to taste like, but I still enjoyed this dish.

As much as I enjoyed the food, I came to the realization that I prefer fried tofu in my curries over the fake meat/shrimp. I think sometimes fake meat can get too chewy for my liking and I think tofu soaks up the curry taste more. I look forward in going to this restaurant again and trying their other dishes! Next time, I will make sure to leave room for dessert because I was way too full!
author: Aiza B.

description:
Soooo grateful for Thai Idea!  The vegan-friendly iced tea and coffee alone are worth the trip.  But even better, the food is delicious, creative, and presented like a five-star restaurant - all at prices comparable to your average omnivore Thai joint.  It's always refreshing to go somewhere and know that I can "safely" order anything or almost anything on the menu, and an all-veggie Thai place really needed to happen.  Yet another reason I love living in SF.  YAY!  

Corn tower rocks my socks soooo hard.
author: Keegan R.

description:
Was brought to this vegetarian place unknowingly but to my dismay .. this place is soooo bomb! I almost feel like I can be a vegetarian after coming here.

From the outside, it looks like a pretty pricey restaurant, but they're very reasonable. The food looked very appetizing. Portions were generous, and everything the vegen meat, well, tasted just as good as meat if not better!

 Get the papaya salad. It's not the typical papaya salad you'd expect with the fish sauce, but it is damn delish.

I opted for the Duck curry (not real duck, but looks and tastes just like it!). Flavors are all there and not overwhelming. Smother that sauce over your optional brown rice and you've got one hell of a meal.

Def coming back to steal Susy C's foursquare mayorship.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Wingstop has nothing on Thai Idea's Wing Bomb, according to my girlfriend.

I have been vegetarian for most of a decade and have never had Wingstop, but do wholeheartedly agree with her that the Wing Bomb is one of the best chicken drummettes I have ever had. If you only eat small portions like my girlfriend does, an order of this four-piece appetizer and some rice will fill you up.

The first entree we had was the Bangkok Duck, which was deliciously accompanied by a sweet tamarind sauce. I rarely eat duck -  vegetarian or otherwise - so providing a comparison between this dish and other duck entrees would be worthless. The bottom line is that my girlfriend and I both enjoyed this dish tremendously, although she didn't like the outside breading, whereas I did.

I found the Thai IDEA Beef to be pleasant. I generally do not like mock beef, as it is usually chewy. This dish was not an exception, but that isn't to say I didn't find it delightful. The Panang Avocado Shrimp curry was the only unsatisfactory part of our meal. The shrimp wasn't very tasty; the curry itself was decent, but nothing special.

We complimented our meal with the Lychee Iced Tea, which was flavorful, but incredibly sweet - to the point where we had to mix in a good amount of water.

It has been some time since I have been excited about trying a new restaurant. Moreover, I can't remember the last time I was this content after tasting a new restaurant's food.
author: Victor L.

description:
Let's get one thing straight, I am NOT their target audience.  I normally eat things like bacon wrapped ribs, sausages covered in chili, and steaks the size of a small child.

So take this review with a grain of salt.  Or with a lump of soy protein.

I got the Thai Idea Beef.  The faux meat emulated the real thing good enough.  The sauce was good but not too spicy (I ordered it Thai Hot).  It had a little bit of a syrupy sweet thing going on that I didn't care for so much.  And the prices were a bit higher than most of the Thai in the neighborhood--I guess those soy cows are a bit pricier than the mooing ones.

The restaurant itself was really cozy and pretty; I almost wish I had eaten in instead of takeout.

I guess what it comes down to is that  when I do vegetarian, I want something that's good because it's meant to be vegetarian; not something that tries to emulate the real thing.

That said, I'd love to go with a group and sample a few of their other offerings.  Hopefully that will be worth another star!
author: Rocco B.

description:
OMG I never had such flavorful and good thai food that is vegan, very small and busy, but it is worth it! 

recommend:
Cononut shrimp curry!! and the amount its huge, it is all worth the money.

the bad thing about this is in a bad neighborhood, beware!
author: karla s.

description:
I think it's been a while since I handed out a five star review (I've been trying to be conservative with five star ratings), but there is no way this place deserves any less.  Oh my God.  The flavor, the presentation, the portions... everything is awesome!  We didn't go for any fake meats -- we just went ahead and ordered everything with tofu.  Several curries and pad thais later, we were happily stuffed.  Definitely enough food to eat family style with four people. :)  

My recommendations - the Pad thai and the Pumpkin curry, but honestly, you probably can't go wrong.

Note - It may not be in the nicest neighborhood, but the inside is very beautifully decorated.
author: Roxana D.

description: Ordered lunch this afternoon through Order Ahead, and it was divine! They were friendly, and my food was ready when I walked in. The pumpkin curry was bursting with flavor, and the Thai samosas were still crispy when I ate them back at the office. I'll be back for sure!
author: Meghan D.

description: I am not a vegetarian. However, I must admit that here the food is really good. So tastie. I d definitely recommend this place
author: Luigi P.

description:
Austin the owner personally greeted us and asked that we gave him any feedback when applicable -- I only have positive feedback to share here.

The decor is sophisticated as it even made me forget that  I was in TL. The food is amazing. Be sure to take your skeptical carnivore friends to try the veggie beef vindaloo curry. They will be converted  instantaneously.
author: Robecta M.

description: Amazing! Although they have very dismal surroundings, the decorum on the inside is impeccable. They are extremely attentive and come around refilling water every 2 minutes. They switched out utensils and gave large portions with matched their pricing. Mango fried rice also came with vegan shrimp and meat, something that I wasn't aware of receiving, but was well received. Was delicious and the vegan meats were identical to the real meat. If I became vegan, I'd go here everyday!
author: Michael T.

description: Ignore the scuzzy neighborhood.  The food, atmosphere, and servers at this Thai restaurant are superb!  Everything is delicious.  Not too spicy; quite mild & tasty.   And if you're a member of the San Francisco Vegetarian Society, you show your membership card & get a discount at this wonderful restaurant.
author: Amalia A.

description:
One of the best restaurants in SF, in my humble opinion. 

The food is good, the presentation is beautiful, the place is cozy, and the staff is very friendly. The prices are relatively cheap so this can easily work for a quick casual meal or for something a bit more intimate or festive. I think the only reason they're not more popular is the location, if they were on Valencia they'd be turning people away.
author: Bourbon S.

description:
OH...MY...GAW! 

Within the past week or two I've passed this little gem a few times thinking, "What? Thai Vegetarian in the TL?!" and realized I needed to eat here soon. Well, today I went in and it did not disappoint!!! 

I walked in and was immediately greeted by smiles and an extremely friendly staff.  I wanted take-out and the owner, Pop, helped me decide on my dish. I knew I wanted  a noodle dish, and something different from my usual Pad Thai, so Pop helped me decide on (excuse my horrible translation) "Drunken Spice Noodle" with veggie "chicken"....HELLO!! They have veggie "chicken, beef, shrimp, or vegetable substitutes!!! 

I cannot express how extremely sweet Pop was. I also noticed the staff standing around with eager smiles to help as well. Something that I look for in restaurants is if the staff is happy or not, and everyone here was so friendly and happy! Great work!! 

I'm eating my food right now and it's absolutely delicious. (actually, it's getting a bit cold because I was so excited to write this review instead!) the food is great, and my take-out came with fresh shaven beets & carrots on the side. I LOVE BEETS! You can definitely tell that a lot of genuine love went into the dish, the decor, and the service :)

The decor is absolutely beautiful. When I walked in it was this cute mellow beat music that wasn't too loud but definitely droned out the TL sounds. People, this place is a HALF-BLOCK from Brenda's. I cannot urge you enough to come here instead and have a delicious meal! 

Best of luck with the new restaurant, I will definitely be back :)
author: Jenalee H.

description:
This is the best vegan/vegetarian Thai food I have ever had. All of the dishes taste like regular, meaty Thai (as others have mentioned) without the creepy fake meat. There were 6 of us and we tried a little bit of everything. For an appetizer we had the firecracker balls, which is a veggie ahi tuna roll. I used to LOVE sushi and this tasted like the real thing. The Tom Kha was very tasty and so was the pumpkin curry. The service was great and fast and the waitress was able to divide the check up to accommodate our large group.

My only complaint is the location and parking. The restaurant itself is fantastic.
author: Celia B.

description: Enjoyed the space, food, and prompt service. The food was fresh, delicious and the right serving temperature. I had the red curry with soft tofu, Thai iced tea (one of the best), and the fresh rolls as an appetizer.
author: Liz S.

description:
Beautifully presented. 

We went two weeks after it had opened and had a nice chat with the owner. I cannot recall his name, but I'll go with Mr. P. He had originally worked at Osha Thai and decided to create a vegeterian/vegan restaurant based on the food he loved making and eating.   

The place is gorgeous and the food is plated beautifully!  The owner was personable and friendly. You can tell he took pride in what he did.

-The wing bombs are AWESOME. I could not tell it was faux chicken.
-Crab cakes was good and so was the corn fritter.
-Their yellow lamb curry vindaloo was FANTASTIC!
-Pad thai is grreattttt!

Admittedly, I judge restaurant restrooms though it has absolutely nothing to do with food.  I walked in the bathroom and it smelled new, in which I later found out they opened 2 weeks ago. Ah ha!
author: Amy L.

description: Friendly servers, nice ambience, horrible food! My BF and I ordered samosas which were well presented but were almost empty pockets of over fried dough. The hot and sour soup was barely lukewarm and filled with what seemed like once frozen or canned veggies and raw, cold tofu bathed in a broth of bland ginger water. The pad eggplant was lukewarm, tasteless and once again filled with frozen or canned veggies. We have no idea how this place generates such amazing reviews. Yuck. Compared to the Burmese Kitchen, where we ate a phenomenal meal the night before a block away, this place rates 0 stars.
author: Rosemary L.

description:
This place is a true gem - serving artfully presented and delicious cuisine.  While I am not a vegetarian, I did not miss meat in my meal today.    In fact, the mock chicken was simply amazing, crispy on the outside and savory on the inside.  

This is a new restaurant and there were a few rough edges in its table service.  I expect that will improve.  Based on the quality and presentation of the cuisine, however, it is also a true bargain.   

Maybe because the food looked like a meal one would spend $75 per person for instead of the $15 per person (appetizer, tax and tea included) we spent, I expected high end waiter service.   I expected fast attention and waiter memory of what was requested.  I am willing to forgive these minor lapses.  

In sum, highly recommended.
author: David L.

description:
Jewel in the Tenderloin

Vegetarian nirvana!  This little gem is a welcome surprise that does not disappoint on any level.  From the service, to the food, to the ambiance, this place is amazing.  The moment you step inside, you are made to feel special: you're greeted by the warmest, most welcoming staff, and the environs are comfortable, delightful, and classy.  So much so, you won't want to leave.  

This is just what the T-loin needed: a classy, delightful, warm and welcoming vegetarian establishment that simply shines.  

Service, food, ambiance -- no details are sacrificed.  Food is topped with a beautiful garnish (my dish was crowned with an orchid), and we were given complimentary soup which was divine!

This is my new favorite place in the T-loin.  

(On a return trip, I ordered the Larb, but regrettably, it didn't have any lime, mint or cilantro on it, which left me questioning and not very happy.  Even so, I'm going to go back and try more dishes.  The place is too wonderful to ditch based on this isolated experience.)
author: Sherry G.

description:
I think I give this a 3.5, but am rounding down because everyone is saying it is SO GOOG... Well, for fake-meat thai food, this is pretty good.  A good selection of dishes where you choose yer protein, tasty, a little bit spicey, not too bad all in all.  BUT - for Thai food in SF, it's nothing special.  In fact, it's a little bit off....

We had the pumpkin curry (beef) and pad kee mow (tofu).  The curry was ok, but kind of bland - not much spice, not much bite, not much flavor.  Even the pure pumpkin pieces lacked flavor.  The dish did not come with rice, although it was the kind I like - that long grain brown rice with different colored particles that I can only find in asian restaurants.

The Pad Kee Mow had a lot of potential - it had a nice bit of heat to it (although the whole chilis offset every few bites), and the tofu was excellent.  I definitely preferred the tofu to the fake beef in the previous dish.  But there were SO MANY ONIONS.  And not enough noodles.  So the dish was not very satisfying or filling.  The bell peppers were obviously out of season too.  Anyway - I wanted to like this dish, but it fell flat on a lot of ways.

All in all, I thought this place was a little expensive, although good if you were in the neighborhood.  But two dishes (no apps, no drinks) went for a little over 25 dollars, so I don't think I'd plan a trip out to the TL to eat here again.
author: Tmon B.

description:
OMG.
My vegan friend turned me onto this place.
They actually know how to do spicy.
The menu is creative and delicious.  On our first time, we were practically planning our next visit.  
Lots of faux-meat and plain ole vegetarian options.
Trendy, hip, youngster atmosphere, but we were able to hang!
author: Ken B.

description: Food is always on point and delicious. Great selections and options for meat eaters and non-meat eaters. Food comes out fairly quickly and tastes fresh. Service is courteous and prompt. Overall a great spot for lunch or dinner solo or among friends. :)
author: Cathy B.

description:
This place is a real gem!  Food is fresh and made with love.  Beautiful presentation.  Owner, chef and waitress are really nice people.  I was on a restricted diet for a few weeks and they went out of their way to accommodate my crazy requests.

Best MasaMan Curry I have ever had.  Delicate curry with fresh veggies and very lightly fried tofu.  The brown rice is incredible and unlike any I have ever had.  Soft and so flavorable.  The papaya salad is excellent.

I love that there is always parking.   I will gladly drive from the Richmond to enjoy food here.
author: Cynthia R.

description:
Wing bombs were okay, not better or worse than any other faux-chicken drumsticks I've had.

Firecracker balls were just okay. They were overcooked, which is kind of a deal breaker for small fried items like this. This item is overpriced, in my opinion: it comes out to about a dollar a ball for these little tiny firecracker balls

Chicken pad-see-ew was decent, nothing to write home about. 

Bangkok duck was good, but it looked it's just store-bought vegetarian goose stuffed with (delicious) beans and mushrooms and other goodies. The sauce was too sweet with the duck but tasted great as a dressing for the salad the duck was served on.

The lamb yellow curry was excellent; it might even be some of the best yellow curry I've ever had. It was a little tiny, tint bit on the sweet side but that was easily remedied by adding some crushed pepper from the spice tray. The crushed pepper tasted very fresh, despite clumping together in a way that suggested it might not have been properly stored (or maybe it's just so drag it was still a little moist?). The portions of lamb were very generous.

Most of our food came out warm as opposed to hot, which probably negatively impacted my impressions of it, but the service was great otherwise and the meal was decent with some at least one standout dish. I'll probably eat here again.
author: Jay S.

description:
Selected this restaurant while residing at the Hilton San Francisco and attending a conference there.  Walkable distance, about 15 min walk.

The food was delicious and beautiful to look at including the appetizers.. This is probably the first and only 100% vegetarian Thai restaurant that I have been to.  The fake lamb entree was excellent.  Others in the group included carnivores who also enjoyed their meals.  The fake shrimp apparently was not the best as it apparently did not taste like real shrimp.

They should come up with a better restaurant name perhaps.
author: Htwo H.

description:
"Fake duck? What? Really. Really? Hah. Okay, fine, fake duck, why not, let's go for it."

(Soon to be followed by, "Whoa. Fake duck! Who knew!")
author: Peter B.

description: We did a quick pit-stop here en-route to Sausalito, and while the food here seemed really healthy, it wasn't up there with the taste side of things. It is possible that we ordered the wrong dishes, but I don't feel like I'll go back to try more.
author: Vivek R.

description:
Food was great and reasonably priced.  There are lots of different options, some more healthy than others.  And portions are very generous.

The dining room was very pleasant.  But it got loud very quickly, so hard having a conversation with a large group.

Service was excellent.  They even gladly provided us with separate checks!
author: Jane D.

description:
Thai Idea..you had me at hello. I never ever get this excited about a vegetarian restaurant. When I was younger, I had a bad experience at a vegetarian restaurant and thought all fake meat tasted gross. But I fell in love with Thai Idea and their dishes...this place is a nice refreshing option to the other places here in the TL. Been here about twice since they've opened, and will def come back more to try their other dishes.

beware..their mild/med hot is still pretty hot lol
author: Jocelyn W.

description: Got takeout here- it was great!
author: Laleh J.

description: such an unique restaurant, wow this place is so good!  almost everything has a sweet sauce but it worked.  I love the golden cauliflower, crab cakes and pad basil with fake ground chicken - better than the real version.  I don't love the wing bomb nearly as much, which are big pieces of fried soy protein.  can't wait to return to try more dishes!
author: Wakako U.

description:
AMAZING vegan thai food! Really great presentation of the food. It's such a treat not to smell fish sauce in your "veggie" thai food.
The options here are really great and the price isn't bad. I would love to go back again and can't wait.
author: G J J.

description: love the food a vegetarain/vegan/thai restraunt it rocks love healthy ethical eating
author: Leigh G.

description:
Pad kee mow was awesome, panang curry was good, and pad thai was average.  The fried tofu appetizer was very good, too... loved their peanut sauce!  The brown rice portion (we needed it only for 1 person) was WAY too big and needlessly expensive.  Maybe we made a mistake in ordering, and they thought that we wanted it for the entire table (and the next table, too).  We didn't try any of the fake "meat" dishes... just sounds wrong.  
They have no alcohol whatsoever at this place, just FYI.  The food and friendly service make up for it, though.
author: Vandana N.

description: I ordered one of the 2 'Tom' soups and then the supposedly highly rated pineapple fried rice. The soup was good -- more veggies than broth. The pineapple rice dish was very, very weird. The faux meat (tofu protein based, I assume) is just odd.....There were like 3-4 mystery 'meats', all with different processed textures and flavors, none of which was particularly memorable or appetizing. I've had better faux meat in NYC at other vegan restaurants....The garnish on the entree was pretty with the orchid, but the bed of shredded beets and cut cucumbers were dry, as if prepared days in advance....
author: World T.

description:
AMAZING!!!  The Wing Bombs are my FAVORITE ever!!  Also, the Volcano Beef is mind blowing.  My friend who is an omni couldn't actually tell the difference!  The food is great, the service is amazing!  The Vegan Thai Iced Tea makes my day.

Get here A.S.A.P.!
author: Callie N.

description: I had never been to an all-vegetarian Thai restaurant and this one did not disappoint!  I definitely want to go back and try their fake meat dishes because I opted for my all time fave thai dish- green curry with fried tofu.  It was reallllllly good and spicy like I requested.  We ordered take-out and it was pretty quick and the service was friendly.
author: Daisy A.

description:
I make it a point to stop by every time I am in SFO

Great people and high integrity!!

THE FOOD IS UNBELIEVABLE AND THE TASTE EXPLODES IN UR MOUTH!  

Can u tell I really like this place! U won't be sorry!!

Maple S get a life!
author: Pilot J.

description:
I am not a vegetarian so I was skeptical at first. This was my first experience with "veggie meat" and I can say I definitely will eat it again (which is a lot to say about a food posing as another food because I'm usually not into that).  Here is a breakdown of the food I tried:

Tom Kha - This coconut soup was delicious! It had lots of great veggies in it. I generally like Tom Kha a little spicy so I may ask if they can do it that way next time but regardless it was super tasty.

Volcanic Beef - The "veggie beef" had the texture and taste of very tender beef.  The presentation of the dish was beautiful. It was pretty spicy and very tasty. The onion ring on top was a yummy touch.

Garlic and Pepper - This dish usually comes with a choice of chicken, beef, tofu or shrimp (all veggie of course). I decided that since I had never tried these "meats" that I would go for a combo of chicken, beef and shrimp. The sauce was wonderful and I used it all over my rice. The beef was the same kind that was in the volcanic beef. The shrimp was a little weird to see since it was shaped like and felt like shrimp but wasn't. I think I might actually like the veggie shrimp better than real shrimp because I didn't have to wonder if the dish would taste fishy. The chicken was really flavorful but I wasn't diggin the texture (this is personal preference though). This is a great dish to get to try the different meats and there are lots of great veggies in it too.

Thai Iced Tea - Standard and very good

If you are looking for a vegetarian experience that non-veg people will enjoy this is it. I will definitely be back.
author: Brittany M.

description:
Just to add to my husband Curran H.'s review my impressions of  our meal from Thai Idea:

CRAB CAKE: Nice texture and crunchiness, although they seemed pretty much like ground tofu with some seaweed mixed in.  Surprised that the sauces came on top rather than as dips.  The fried potatoes and salad garnish were a nice touch though.

ROASTED DUCK CURRY:  About half way through this dish, I finally found some veggie meat product floating in the sea of far-too-rich coconut red curry sauce.  I'm sure that the " roast duck" was the same stuff we get out of a can for $1.50 from the Vietnamese market a block away.  There were also some underdone red bell pepper and tomato wedges and canned pineapple chunks.  I can see why the person who took our order thought that I should get some rice to soak up the sauce and make it seem like there was more substance to the dish.

PAD SEE EW with Shrimp:  This was my husband's dish and I only had a bite of it, but I have to say that their supposed "wok hei" noodles were not a patch on Sam Wo's for more than twice the price.

I'm not as optimistic as he is about giving this restaurant another chance, but if he's buying...
author: Kelly H.

description:
The only reason I do not give this establishment five stars is because I need to go back and check for consistency. I truly see this restaurant as a symbol of San Francisco's rich culture. This is a restaurant with excellent service--and not oddball, vegan hippy service--and all the right dishes that you would barely know (if you did not know) you were in a vegetarian restaurant. 

A Thai restaurant is often judged by the quality of its rice. In being a vegetarian restaurant, brown rice could have been high quality and high taste, low quality and low taste (more than norm), or somewhere in between. The rice achieved it all, and it looked good to boot. The tofu is as good and as well-prepared as you can find in China or Taiwan, and the accompaniments were all there. 

Service was the crown jewel of this establishment. It felt small without feeling cramped or too "local." The waitress was expedient without being brash. All the while, I conducted a business-oriented lunch, for which it was a fantastic venue. 

I will return.
author: Ryan M.

description: Small restaurant, nice ambience, friendly people and great food. Had the Pad Kee Mow, simply brilliant display of the cuisine and just tastes wonderful! And they served it in no time. Great place for a family dinner and even for having a good time with friends!
author: Aditya R.

description:
The food is delicious! They use the high quality kind of artificial meat made from soy protein in their food so you can hardly tell it's not real meat. 

The only downside is the place is a bit pricey. I ordered a bowl of curry, lychee iced tea, and split a wing bomb with my friend and it ended up being about $25 each for everything.
author: Bonnie S.

description:
I have to confess, I'm very much an omnivore... I loves me some meat, and although I'd really like to become a vegetarian I often lack the willpower...

On the bright side, I only live a few blocks away from Thai Idea! They have some of the best mock-meat I've ever tasted, along with some of the prettiest food displays I've ever seen. The staff is incredibly friendly, and the chef / owner clearly has a passion for his trade. 

Pretty much everything I've had there so far is good, but there's an item they serve that's not on the menu and you definitely need to ask for it. The chef makes a sort of Thai / Vietnamese crepe with mock duck and spicy plum sauce, and it's totally amazing. Maybe if we request it enough, he'll add it to the new menus. Wink-wink.
author: Kathleen P.

description:
5 star yelp rated restaurant with a 2 star price.  Great place to impress your date.  
v32 Pumpkin curry was Great.  Would you believe the yum woon sen (clear noodles) was better than the Pad Thai?
v11Som Tum, green papaya salad was done perfectly.

It was exciting  to see vegetables used to decorate the  dishes.  

"Pop', the owner did a great job decorating the place and he really took care of my 22 person dinner party.

Monday to Friday at 5:51pm,go grab a parking space...tons of free parking after 6pm!   Go for the yellow zones and parking meters.  So no excuse not able to get free parking.

This place will keep on shining.
author: Sunny O.

description:
I found this place by way of a friend's suggestion - he had never been. So I called and made a reservation for a party of 27 for my non-dairy, fish only ( not vegan, but damn near)  boyfriend's birthday. 
The reason we took the plunge is because we missed Thai Corner in oakland so much that we felt we could not NOT give this place a chance...

Before we even got there, I spoke to the manager. His name is Pop and he accommodated me/us with such grace and practicality, guiding me through my options on the menu so that it was cost effective and idiot proof (me being the idiot) to the point that I am a customer for as long as they are open.

The decor is clean and modern befitting an intimate dinner or a large party in the one room dinning area. Familiar hints of Thai restaurant embellishments are tastefully added...
Our food was promptly brought out as we all found our seats. Every dish had a unique presentation and EVERY DISH WAS PERFECT.  From appetizers to dessert and attentiveness of staff, I would give Thai Idea 10 stars if I could. Even the carni/omnivores were impressed, and we're talking straight "where's the beef?" kind of folks !  

So if you and your honey are different types of eaters, I promise you both will leave full and happy to return. Vegan Thai food is difficult to do properly, and these people rock it out.
Thanks, Pop! you'll be seeing many of us again very soon!
author: bender m.

description:
I am a vegetarian who lives in the TL, and I do most of my cooking and a *lot* of my shopping locally at the markets in Little Saigon. That is why I was very disappointed today -- on a day when I am recovering from a bad flu and just needed my partner to pick me up some simple, healthy food to-go -- that Thai Idea put old tofu that had gone off and fermented, into my soup.

You see, I know my local tofu, too. The tofu they used was Wo Chong's fresh tofu, which is distributed in large brown boxes, and oftentimes sold in local Asian markets at 5 pieces of tofu per dollar. Wo Chong is really good local tofu... but it doesn't keep well unless properly stored in a cold environment, and replaced with fresh water, ideally twice a day. Part of the problem could be that the restaurant ran out of stock and went to one of the local markets for fresh tofu. Unfortunately, the local markets aren't always very good at keeping their tofu fresh either, which is a problem I have experienced before, and which can cause diarrhea and stomach upset. 

If you want great tofu, go straight to Wo Chong in Chinatown, get it same-day fresh, and either eat it immediately or put it in a container with lots of water and store it in your fridge. But for a restaurant -- especially a vegetarian restaurant -- to serve a customer bad tofu is unacceptable, even if they have otherwise great food... which Thai Idea does. 

Sorry, but healthiness and freshness of the food comes first, and is a problem that must be addressed. For this reason, I must give Thai Idea 1 star -- and deny them my business -- until such point as they make a clear effort to correct this problem.
author: Mark K.

description: I have been to many vegan places in the past and I found this place pretty ordinary in terms of taste. The portions are very small and I couldn't find the real value to the money you pay. Most of the "supposed to be crispy items are soft and saggy. The service is not prompt as I observed only 2 servers serving for the entire crowd.
author: Srikanth D.

description:
As an update, this place still rocks!  I have not had a bad meal here at all and I've encouraged other co-workers to try this place and they have been equally as impressed. It's now busy during lunch but not so busy that you have to wait for a table just yet.  It's good to see the business picking up as the word of mouth has gotten around.

My go-to dish now seems to be the Yellow Curry over rice (pick your faux meat of choice). Yummy and addicting.
author: Nelson W.

description: Friendly staff, very nice environment, wonderful presentation and fantastic taste! The crab cakes were exceptional. This is far from just another Thai vegetarian restaurant.
author: Michael K.

description: What a find!!!!  It is so delicious and so beautiful and the prices are quite reasonable.  The decor is great.  The waiter was helpful and super nice.  The fact that it is vegetarian is a huge plus for me, but I believe non-vegetarians will find it delicious as well.   I'll be back often.
author: Melinda C.

description:
I was hoping this place would stay a secret tucked away in the civic center, but the secret is definitely out and that is definitely for a good reason.  I love fake meat when it's done well - there's less guilt, but you still get the complex textures in your meal - and this place definitely does fake meat well!

The chicken satay is much more tender than the dried out debreaded chicken fingers I've been given in other Thai restaurants and vegi-prawns?! who knew they'd be that close to the real thing!
author: William C.

description: To put it simply, this is the BEST restaurant I've ever been at in SF. And I eat outside a lot. Food is delicious!
author: Jorge Luis M.

description: This little place served real tasty dishes. We had the crispy tofu, papaya salad & summer rolls, everything was good. Except that their summer rolls had a very soft rice wrapping which is not usual, maybe cuz it's vegan but I prefer the traditional wrapping. The place packed up pretty quickly with a line outside on a Saturday nite. Seatings are comfortable although crowded and service was speedy and reasonably friendly.
author: Carol W.

description:
Great Thai food...was very pleased to order from a full Thai Menu
The place looks a bit shady from outside but was very good inside.
Service was very good with a big smile and prompt

Food Tasted very good - we ordered coconut milk soup, red curry and Pineapple fired rice. Every dish was yummy.
Loved their complimentary Broccoli soup....
The serving size was big with very reasonable prices.
author: anya a.

description:
After the previous night's frustration at Osha Thai, trying to figure out which of their "vegetarian dishes" were, in fact, vegetarian (answer: not very many at all!), I was still craving a good Thai curry. So tonight, we made our way over to Thai Idea Vegetarian in the Tenderloin.

I was blown away. First, the place is very nicely decorated. Far, far, nicer than I had come to expect in the 'Loin. Think Pacific Heights. More importantly, the food was great. And the presentation was 5-star. Very creative.

Everything we had was excellent. Well spiced, freshly prepared, beautifully presented. Servings were large. This place instantly became my favorite Thai in SF--thankfully erasing the bitter taste from Osha (the night before!) Okay, I'll still venture out to Khan Toke, the best atmosphere, and sold food, but Thai Idea is the new standard!
author: Channon H.

description:
Best way to break up jury duty!  I got the dreaded jury duty notice and as we broke for lunch on day one, I looked up the closest good lunch place.  Thai idea popped up so I decided to check it out.

Wow - impressed.  During lunch hour, it was easy to get a table.  The server was friendly and nice.

I ordered the Pad Ped which was a vegetable/tofu rice place sauteed with red curry paste.  It was super fresh, steaming hot upon arrival, and really spicy.  So good!  

While I hate jury duty, I'd definitely come back to Thai Idea!
author: Sameer D.

description: This food is amazing, my meat loving husband enjoys their mock lamb and I can't get enough of their mock crab cakes and pad basil. The service is amazing, beautifully put together and served within 10-15 minutes.  It's great for date night or to go. Thank you for a lovely vegan delight! P. S. Try the fried bananas and coconut sorbet, you will believe heaven is real!
author: Sierra P.

description: I can't wait to come here again. It's my new fav Thai Place. Servers are super attentive and accommodating. I had the tom yum veggie cat fish and it was yummy. They customized the crepe for us too. Delish!
author: P P.

description: Second time was just as great. Brought our own wine this time - no corkage fee.
author: Mark S.

description:
Wow. Words cannot express how much I loved this place! The Pad Kee Mow was the best I've ever had -- just the right amount of spice. I sampled my friends' dishes as well and all of them were delicious! Each entree was served with a fresh orchid on top. I can't believe how affordable this place was -- everything was presented beautifully. I would go back to San Francisco just to eat here again. FYI: They do not serve alcohol, but let you bring your own or buy it from the liquor store next door.

This place is a MUST if you're visiting, even if you aren't vegetarian!
author: Kaylee L.

description:
It's so-so. The food is good but not great. Taking the price into consideration, it is less appealing than many other restaurants in SF.

We ordered satay 'chicken'. The 'chicken' itself taste rather sweet, and so is mixed vegetable. We like Panang prawn with avocado. This dish is also on the sweet, but the avocado sort of balance it out.
author: Lionel W.

description:
The beautiful decor is definitely a sharp contrast to the view outside of the restaurant, and once you're inside, you might forget where you are. The waitstaff is pleasant and attentive, and the food is inventive and tasty. I'm usually a little skeptical about vegetarian restaurants, but Thai Idea did not disappoint. I would have liked to try everything, but there's only so much I can eat in one sitting.

Our first appetizer was the veggie Chicken Satay. It had a nice texture, and it worked well with the peanut sauce which had just the right amount of heat to it.

Our second appetizer was the Crab Cakes. They had a lot of flavor to them, but they didn't really taste like what I remember crab tasting like... They were crunchy and tasty, though.

My entree was the Pineapple Fried Rice. I chose it because I wanted to try the maximum amount of different fake meats, and that had three of them in it. The shrimp is kind of weird in that it looks like shrimp, but it's way chewier and it smells a little seaweedy. The beef and chicken were both delicious. There was a nice pineapple to rice to egg ratio as well.

Had I not eaten so much, I would have gone for dessert. I also went a little crazy on the Thai Iced Teas... sooo excellent.

Unfortunately, when we left, happy and satiated, we ran into a homeless guy taking a dump on the side of the building right next to where we parked...
author: Leelah P.

description: one of the best places to get vegan thai in san fransico! the fried banana ice cream is delish!
author: Vivvi T.

description: I don't think I have ever written a review on a Thai restaurant in SF; the food is always so mediocre, I never feel moved to comment.  Thai Idea is fantastic.  The curries are the highlight, with very fresh vegetables.  Tends to run very spicy, so our our of medium spice was a bit too much and next time we will get mild.  But it is phenomenal.  Better than anything we have had in the City in over 10 years.
author: Tamara G.

description: Love this place!  It's our go to in the hood for great vegetarian Thai food and the ambiance is well above what you get at other places nearby with similar prices.  As mentioned by other reviewers it's really nice for a vegetarian to be able to walk into a place and order ANYTHING off the menu.
author: Dustin R.

description: Delicious and amazing vegetarian Thai food. I will definitely come back here again. This service is amazing and the atmosphere is great. I tried the pad thai nd coconut juice and I will most definitely recommend coming back here.
author: Kelly C.

description: Very good asian food. Vegetarian duck. If you can make this into the best tasty duck, all is possible. We all had different dishes and each dish was good (2 thai dishes, one indian curry, and one Chinese dish). And the wine (Cabernet Sauvignon) was also very good and accomodating. Service excellent.
author: Ivo K.

description:
My husband and I ate here over our recent honeymoon.  We ordered the firecracker balls, yellow lamb curry, and spicy lemongrass beef.
